citation.article-title: Oribaculum catoniae gen. nov., sp. nov.; Catonella morbi gen. nov., sp. nov.; Hallella seregens gen. nov., sp. nov.; Johnsonella ignava gen. nov., sp. nov.; and Dialister pneumosintes gen. nov., comb. nov., nom. rev., Anaerobic gram-negative bacilli from the human gingival crevice.

p.s: Hallella (Hall.el'la. N. L. masc. n. Hallella, in honor of Ivan C. Hall, a United States microbiologist)

Hallella cells are obligately anaerobic, gram-negative, nonmotile, nonsporing rods that ferment carbohydrates and produce major amounts of succinic acid, moderate to major amounts of acetic acid, and moderate amounts of lactic acid.
The major constituents of cells grown in PYG broth without serum include C16:0 fatty acid, C16:03-0H fatty acid, iso-C16:0 fatty acid, iso-C14:0 fatty acid, and C14:0 fatty acid.
The type species is Hallella seregens.
The G+C content of the DNA of the type species is 58 mol%.

The genus can be differentiated from phenotypically similar taxa by its cellular fatty acid profile, particularly the relatively large amounts of C16:03-OH, iso-C16:0, and iso-C14:0 fatty acids produced, and by the high G+C content of its DNA.
